docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The coverage of cybersex on May 16 is a perfect illustration of how the term ''addiction'' has become politicized. There are millions of equally compulsive Internet users who spend their time shopping, day trading, chatting or playing games rather than looking at sexually oriented material, but we don't call them addicts because we don't disapprove of the underlying behavior. That interest in sex is singled out for especially derogatory attention says more about the sickness of society than about the ''addicts.'' MARC DESMOND New York

docs.lead_paragraph: For children who need medical attention at hospitals, the danger may not end when they are placed in ambulances. A recent study by researchers at Johns Hopkins Children's Center found that it was not uncommon for patients and medical equipment to be unsecured as ambulances sped to the hospital.

headline.main: For Children, a Safer Race to the Hospital

docs.abstract: Study finds that people being taken to hospitals in ambulances, especially children, face undue risk because they or the medical equipment on board may not be properly secured; photo (S)
docs.snippet: For children who need medical attention at hospitals, the danger may not end when they are placed in ambulances.    A recent study by researchers at Johns Hopkins Children's Center found that it was not uncommon for patients and medical equipment to...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''On Left-Handedness, Its Causes and Costs'' (May 16): The geneticist Amar Klar seems to be on the right track when he says, ''I'm not interested in handedness per se, I'm interested in how the brain works.'' It is well documented that the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body (and certain cognitive functions, primarily intellectual and analytical), and that the right side of the brain controls the left side of the body (and other cognitive functions, primarily creative). Thus, the idea of a genetic marker for predisposed right- or left-handedness would seem to be valid only if it affected the formation of the brain itself.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Need the coverage of ''cybersex addictions'' on May 16 have been framed in such sex-negative terms? Some see the Internet as a new ground for healthy experimentation and role-playing -- a safe alternative to premature action and a welcome counter to the erotic inertia that can keep people from discovering potentially fulfilling tastes and satisfying flavors. To me, it makes sense that upon the first inkling of additional tastes and flavors, someone would invest some time exploring. If the results get people to rethink old relationships and jobs, well, great.

docs.lead_paragraph: First it was mice that could eat to their hearts' content without getting fat. Now it's mice that can hold their alcohol better and recover from it faster. First, scientists at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey reported that they had created a genetically modified mouse that could eat with abandon. The long-term objective is better understanding of human obesity.

headline.main: A Mouse Made for Heavy Drinking

docs.abstract: Scientists at University of Washington create a mouse that drinks much more alcohol than a normal mouse and that may therefore be useful in study of alcoholism; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In '' 'Revolutionary Etude,' Rendered by a Wren'' (May 16), I was struck by the question, ''Are there cases when humans, like certain birds, have a sexual response to songs?'' A year ago, we heard Frankie Avalon sing; when he finished, women in the audience went nuts. I said to my wife, ''They're giving him a standing ovulation!'' DR . GEORGE F. GITLITZ Sarasota, Fla.
docs.abstract: Dr George F Gitlitz letter comments on May 16 article on bird song

docs.lead_paragraph: Now, six years after young people in Britain started dying from a human strain of mad cow disease, scientists are still struggling to understand how the disease spreads to humans, how many more will die from it and if a similar epidemic could start in the United States spread by infected deer and elk. While there are no firm answers, clues are being discovered on an almost weekly basis as scientists explore the nature of a mysterious infectious agent called the prion. Unlike disease-causing viruses or bacteria, prions are normal proteins found throughout the body tissues of humans and other animals. But for reasons that are not at all understood, normal prions sometimes transform themselves into tiny particles that cannot be killed with boiling water, chemical disinfectants or strong radiation.

headline.main: Clues to Mad Cow Disease Emerge in Study of Mutant Proteins

docs.abstract: Scientists who study prions, infectious agent responsible for mad cow disease, discuss their research with families of American victims of sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) and medical professionals in Miami; speculate on why new variant CJD attacks young people while sporadic CJD affects much older people; photos; drawing (M)
